                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Teaching and Mentoring for Doctoral Students</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-247" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Teaching and Mentoring Program: Research and Pedagogical Skills</h2>
<p>Our Department is a community of individuals committed to the highest standards in teaching and scholarship in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies. Doctoral students are an integral part of this community. Working closely with supportive faculty members as mentors, doctoral students are encouraged to develop research and pedagogical skills that will prepare them for careers as outstanding teachers and scholars. Besides regular meetings with the Director of Graduate Studies, doctoral students are urged to meet with other departmental faculty to discuss their research and pedagogical interests.</p>
<p>In addition to advice on the research and preparation of term papers, from early on in their graduate studies our doctoral students receive guidance on how to convert their course papers into conference presentations and/or journal articles. Doctoral students are also offered the opportunity to partner with faculty members in research projects, the design of undergraduate courses, the planning of academic conferences and symposia, and the publication of our two scholarly journals, GÃ¡vea-Brown and Brasil/Brazil.</p>
<p>It is the Department's philosophy that teaching and research go hand in hand and are mutually enriching. Our commitment to teaching is reflected in the multiple educational programs of instruction and teacher training supported by the Department and included as part of its curricular offerings and as a service to the surrounding community. The Master's program in Cross-Cultural Education, co-sponsored by the Education Alliance, is a testimony to this pedagogical position and may serve as a methodological and material resource for our students. Furthermore, the emphasis on language in both our undergraduate and graduate programs rests on our belief that the acquisition of a foreign/second language contributes to what Pierre Bourdieu calls the expansion of one's cultural capital in a material, cultural, and symbolic sense. The conviction that language and culture are facets of the same process and cannot be separated permeates all aspects of our graduate program ââ courses, research, examinations, and extra-curricular activities. Doctoral students emerge from our program with linguistic expertise as well as mastery of foreign language pedagogy, in addition to sound research skills. Such combination has proven to be highly attractive to universities seeking junior faculty to fill positions in foreign language, literature and cultural studies, as attested by our very successful record in placing the graduates from our Ph.D. program.</p>
<p>Our doctoral students participate in a mentoring program designed to pass the Department's pedagogical legacy in foreign language, literature and culture on to them while enhancing their teaching skills. According to our longstanding practice, from the very beginning we impart to our doctoral students the belief that immersion in and constant use of Portuguese as the target language, following the principles of a communicative and natural approach, represent crucial steps in the acquisition of a second/foreign language. Furthermore, through both orientation and hands-on experience, our doctoral students quickly learn that foreign/second languages are to be used as media of instruction and not as ends in themselves (such as the traditional objective of solely mastering grammar skills).</p>
<p>The teaching mentoring program consists of a series of steps designed to acquaint our students with various pedagogical approaches and methodologies, while also exposing them to different instructional experiences and course formats:</p>
<p>1. Intensive group orientation before the start of each academic year, consisting of a packet of readings in methodology and applied linguistics as well as an in-house seminar with members of the Department's faculty, culminating in a mock practice teaching session.</p>
<p>2. For each new course that a graduate student will teach or co-teach, an orientation session specific to the goals of each course will be offered prior to the beginning of each semester.</p>
<p>3. In addition to this basic preparation, there will be group and/or individual meetings throughout the semester between teaching assistants/fellows and the faculty member(s) in charge of teacher training, as well as class visitations followed by a discussion between the graduate student and the evaluator. Doctoral students will receive guidance on how to plan lessons, develop a course syllabus, design and grade exams and assignments, etc.</p>
<p>The following courses have been earmarked for the teaching-mentoring program:</p>
<p><strong>POBS 100-200: Elementary Portuguese</strong> â A yearlong course for students with little or no preparation in the Portuguese language. Stress upon fundamental language skills: understanding, speaking, reading, and writing. Aspects of Portuguese and Brazilian culture are also presented. Method: situational/natural approach.</p>
<p><strong>POBS 110: Intensive Portuguese</strong> â Designed for students with little or no preparation in the Portuguese language, it covers the same amount of material as PB10-20 in just one semester. Stress upon fundamental language skills: understanding, speaking, reading, and writing. Aspects of Portuguese and Brazilian culture are also presented. Method: situational/natural approach.</p>
<p><strong>POBS 400: Writing and Speaking Portuguese </strong>â Designed to improve the student's ability in contemporary spoken and written Portuguese, using such cultural items as short stories, plays, films, videos, newspaper and magazine articles, and popular music. Method: situational/natural approach.</p>
<p><strong>POBS 610/620: Mapping Portuguese-Speaking Cultures</strong> â Selected literary and cultural texts that serve as vehicles for a deeper understanding of Portuguese-speaking societies. Literary materials are taken from several genres and periods with special attention to contemporary writings. Other media such as film and music are also included. Considerable emphasis on strengthening speaking and writing skills.</p>
<p>Graduate students will normally progress from co-teaching with a regular faculty member (generally in POBS 110 and/or POBS 400) to teaching their own courses (generally POBS 100-200 and/or POBS 400) under the supervision of a faculty mentor. Whenever possible graduate students will be given the opportunity to teach a module of one of the introduction to literature courses (POBS 610 and/or POBS 620) and, in some cases, to teach such courses on their own.</p>
<p>In addition to the training they receive in the department, students are encouraged to enroll in the Sheridan Center's teaching certificate program, which provides pedagogical and professional training in the form of methodologies, approaches and techniques. The Center also offers invaluable help in the preparation of CVs, narrative profiles on teaching philosophy and teaching portfolios. Students should check the Sheridan Center website for more details.</p>
<p>Depending upon the research and pedagogical interests of individual students, there are also opportunities to teach and conduct research in local public schools as well as to serve as an intern with the Educational Alliance, a Brown unit charged to conduct applied research on educational reform and cultural diversity.</p>
<h6>ASSESSMENT OF STUDENT PERFORMANCE</h6>
<p>When doctoral students first arrive on campus, they meet with the Director of Graduate Studies, who explains the doctoral program to them in detail and guides them in their initial selection of courses. At the end of the first semester, each student's academic performance during the preceding semester and progress towards the completion of the degree are assessed by the Department's faculty. This evaluation is transmitted to students at individual meetings with the DGS. This process occurs every semester of the student's graduate experience at Brown. In addition, students will receive a written assessment of their performance and progress towards the degree at the close of each academic year in accordance with Graduate School regulations.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
  </div>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate Program</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-12" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>Professor Patricia I. Sobral</strong><br /><strong>Director of Undergraduate Studies</strong></p>
<p>The undergraduate program in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies is interdisciplinary in nature and allows students to work with core faculty in the department and in related fields. Since language is the key to culture and the more in-depth study of the Portuguese-speaking world in all of its diversity, the foundation of the undergraduate experience is centered on interdisciplinary arts-based learning approaches. On any given week, students from all levels could be working with digital narratives, creative writing, intense literary analysis, performances, the making of micro-documentaries and visual arts projects.</p>
<p>Another key element to the program is the <a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate-program/clube-da-escrita"><em>Clube da escrita</em></a>, an in-department writing center in which consultants work with each student individually.</p>
<p>At the end of each semester, as a means of honoring student work and sharing with a larger community, undergraduates from all courses perform or show their work at Performance and Exhibit evening. The evening highlights the quality of undergraduate work in the program and underscores the importance of community.</p>
<p>Due to the intensive nature of Portuguese language instruction offered by the Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies and to the opportunities for study in Brazil and in Portugal, it is possible for students to start Portuguese at Brown and still be able to <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate-program/concentration-guidelines" title="Concentration Guidelines" rel="nofollow">become concentrators</a>. In fact, many Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators begin studying Portuguese as freshmen or sophomores.</p>
<p>Additionally, the undergraduate experience in the department is shaped by the lively and active participation of students from concentration programs throughout the university. Many students who ultimately decide to concentrate in other departments choose to integrate Portuguese into their courses of study and continue to take courses or develop projects related to Portuguese and Brazilian Studies.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ul>
</ul>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Clube da Escrita</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-518" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p style="text-align:left"><span style="background-color:transparent">Clube da Escrita is a writing clinic for students of Portuguese. </span><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">&nbsp;</span><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">Writers at all levels benefit from feedback on their work. </span><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">&nbsp;</span><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">Clube da Escrita gives&nbsp;</span><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">students the opportunity to receive one-on-one instruction and guidance about writing in Portuguese from the departmentâs teaching staff. </span></p>
<p style="text-align:left"><strong>Learn more and book appointments on the <a href="https://sites.google.com/a/brown.edu/clubedaescrita/" target="_blank" title="Clube da escrita website"><em>Clube da Escrita </em>website</a>. </strong></p>
<p style="text-align:left"><span style="background-color:transparent; text-align:left">Access to the Clube website is limited to students currently enrolled in participating  classes. If you believe you should have access and are not able to view  the site, please check with your instructor or contact Coordinator <a href="mailto:patricia_martinho_ferreira@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">PatrÃ­cia Ferreira</a>.</span></p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Concentration Guidelines</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-252" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>Professor Patricia I. Sobral</strong><br /><strong>Director of Undergraduate Studies</strong></p>
<p>The concentration in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies is the study of  the Portuguese-speaking world, a large and diverse geographical and  cultural area spread over five continents, including Brazil, Continental  and Insular Portugal, Lusophone Africa and Luso-America, and inhabited  by two hundred million people. Although students are encouraged to  explore the global nature of the Portuguese-speaking world, their  individual program will generally focus on one of the specific  geographical areas mentioned above.</p>
<p>Using the Portuguese language as a basis, the concentration in  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies allows students to develop their  interests in the areas of language, literature, education, history and  the social sciences. The concentration consists of eight interrelated  courses to be selected by the student, in consultation with the Director  of Undergraduate Studies, from the offerings in Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies as well as in other departments, such as History,  Political Science, Afro-American Studies, Anthropology and Sociology. The <strong>prerequisite</strong> for the concentration is POBS 0400 or the equivalent; however, these prerequisites<strong> do not</strong> count toward the 8 concentration requirements.</p>
<p>Beyond introductory language courses, concentration requirements for Portuguese and Brazilian Studies consist of the following courses:</p>
<ul>
<li>POBS 0610 (Mapping Portuguese-Speaking Cultures: Brazil)</li>
<li>POBS 0620 (Mapping Portuguese-Speaking Cultures: Portugal and Africa)</li>
<li>POBS 1030 (Portuguese Stylistics)</li>
<li>POBS 1800 (Concentration Seminar)</li>
<li>Four courses to be selected from the offerings in Portuguese  and Brazilian Studies and/or related departments, such as Africana  Studies, Anthropology, History, Political Science and Sociology<span>&nbsp;</span></li>
</ul>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">DUG (Departmental Undergraduate Group)</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-253" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The Portuguese and Brazilian Studies DUG is a group of students who are interested in creating a sense of community among undergraduates in the department. The DUG is responsible for planning a variety of events to strengthen ties among undergraduates as well as to build connections with faculty and alumni.</p>
<p>For more information about participating in the DUG, please contact:</p>
<h6>Seb Pihan</h6>
<p><a href="mailto:samuel_pihan@brown.edu">samuel_pihan@brown.edu</a></p>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-links"><legend>Related Links</legend><div class="field field-type-link field-field-related-links">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/college/advising/curricular-resource-center/departmental-undergraduate-groups/departmental-undergraduate-groups" target="_blank">Curricular Resource Center information on DUGs</a>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
</fieldset>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">

		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Fellowships, Prizes, and Funding</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-225" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Various prizes, fellowships, and research funds are available to undergraduate students in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies. <span>Students planning to apply for fellowships should  make their  intention known to the Concentration Advisor as early as  possible to  avoid missing deadlines.<span> <br /></span></span></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<h2><span><a name="scarritt"></a>The John and Clarice Scarritt Fund</span></h2>
<p><span>The Scarritt Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies has been  established by Clarice and John A. Scarritt '73, P'09 to support trips  to Brazil by Brown undergraduates for the purpose of conducting research  for theses and participating in internships. Priority is given to  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators and to non-concentrators  who have demonstrated a commitment to Portuguese and Brazilian Studies  through coursework and participation in departmental activities. </span></p>
<p><span>For  more information, please contact Professors <a href="mailto:Patricia_Sobral@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Patricia Sobral</a> and/or <a href="mailto:Luiz_Valente@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Luiz F. Valente<span></span></a>. You can also <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.portuguese-brazilian-studies/files/uploads/ScarrittFundApplication.pdf" title="Scarritt Fund Application">download the application</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/scarritt-fund-projects" title="Scarritt Fund Projects" rel="nofollow">projects that have been supported by the Scarritt Fund</a>.<br /></span></p>
<h2><a name="karina"></a>Karina P. Lago Prize</h2>
<p>Each year one or two senior concentrators are recommended for a  special  prize at graduation. This award recognizes outstanding academic   achievement in the Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentration. In   1995 the award was renamed in memory of Karina Palmira Lago'95, an   outstanding student and exemplary human being, who passed away on   November 6, 1995. The prize was endowed in December, 1997 by a generous   gift from Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Small '63, P '97.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>Learn more about the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/karina-lago-memorial-fund-portuguese-and-brazilian-studies" title="Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" rel="nofollow">Karina Lago Fund</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/karina-p-lago-prize-recipients" title="Karina P. Lago Prize Recipients" rel="nofollow">previous recipients of the prize.</a></span></p>
<h2>Other Fellowships and Honors</h2>
<p>Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators have also competed favorably for national fellowships and university-wide honors:</p>

<p>A large number of Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies concentrators have graduated <strong>"magna cum laude."</strong></p>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Five-Year Integrated A.B./A.M. Degree</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-230" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>This program is intended to articulate undergraduate and graduate  work, but academic requirements for each degree must be separately met.  Students must apply to study in the integrated program no later than the  third week of semester VII.</p>
<p>As many as two courses taken by a student during undergraduate  studies may be offered in partial fulfillment of the requirements for  the Master's degree. At least six semester course units must be taken as  a graduate student. A final project is also required.</p>
<p>For further information, contact <a href="mailto:patricia_sobral@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Patricia Sobral</a> (Concentration Advisor) or <a href="mailto:leonor_simas-almeida@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Leonor Simas-Almeida</a> (Director of Graduate Studies).<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-links"><legend>Related Links</legend><div class="field field-type-link field-field-related-links">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/undergraduate/5th-year-masters-degree" target="_blank">Graduate School: 5th-year Master&#039;s</a>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
</fieldset>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Honors Program</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-223" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>Professor OnÃ©simo T. Almeida</strong><br /><strong>Director of the Undergraduate Honors Program</strong></p>
<p>Candidacy for honors in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies assumes a  better than average record, particularly in the concentration. Students  interested in pursuing honors should make their intention known to the  <a href="mailto:Patricia_Sobral@brown.edu" title="Professor Patricia Sobral" rel="nofollow">Director of Undergraduate Studies</a> and the <a href="mailto:Onesimo_Almeida@brown.edu" title="Professor OnÃ©simo Almeida" rel="nofollow">Director of the Undergraduate  Honors Program</a> early as possible. Candidates for honors are required to  complete an honors thesis or other approved project.</p>
<p>In consultation with the other pertinent faculty, a topic will be  selected and a thesis advisor and second reader will be chosen.  Candidates for honors will normally register for POBS 0193/0194 ("Research  and Preparation of Honors Projects") in Semesters VII and VIII, but  these independent study units may not be used to satisfy the minimum  course requirement for the concentration.</p>
<p>No later than the third week of Semester VII, a candidate for  honors will submit a proposal for approval by the thesis advisor and  second reader. It is expected that the student will meet regularly with  his/her advisor(s) throughout the semester. At the end of Semester VII a  report on the project should be submitted in writing by the student,  signed by the thesis advisor(s) and filed with the concentration  advisor.</p>
<p>The project must be completed in time for the readers to evaluate  it and for possible corrections to be made before a final copy is  submitted. Therefore, for students completing requirements for  graduation in Semester I, the project should be submitted by December 1.  For students completing requirements for graduation in Semester II, the  project should be submitted by April 22. An oral presentation/defense  of the project will follow.</p>
<p>A final copy prepared according to a format approved by the  Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies should be submitted by  January 10 for students completing requirements in Semester I and by May  10 for students completing requirements in Semester II.</p>
<p>Honors candidates are encouraged to examine the copies of <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/honors-program/honors-theses" title="Honors Theses" rel="nofollow">past  honors projects</a> on file at the Department of Portuguese and Brazilian  Studies.</p>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-links"><legend>Related Links</legend><div class="field field-type-link field-field-related-links">
    <div class="field-items">

</div>

				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Honors Theses</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-224" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <ul>
<li>"Brazil through Travel: How the Brazilian  Nation Exists in Orlando, Florida" by Gabriela Camargo (Advisors: Luiz  F. Valente and Patricia Sobral)</li>
<li>"The Portuguese Linguistic Influence in the  Asian Seas and its Historical/Global Repercussions" by Joshua Michael  Marcotte (Advisors: Leonor Simas-Almeida and Nelson Vieira)</li>
<li>"As HarmonizaÃ§Ãµes Culturais do Imigrante:  Life in L(USA)lÃ¢ndia as Portrayed in Portuguese-American literature by  Brianna Medeiros (Advisors: OnÃ©simo Almeida and Leonor Simas-Almeida)</li>
<li>"Entre Palavras" by Gabriela G. Scarritt (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente and Patricia Sobral)</li>
<li>"O Povo de Deus na Terra do Sol:  Ecclesiological Innovation, Liberationist Catholicism and Citizenship in  Brazil" by Benjamin Patterson Brown (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente and  James N. Green)</li>
<li>"Things Unsaid: A Collection of the Short  Fiction of SÃ©rgio Sant'Anna" [Translation with an Introduction] by  Patrick Andrew Browne (Advisors: Nelson H. Vieira and Leonor  Simas-Almeida)</li>
<li>"Dualism in the Lives and Literary Fiction  of Machado de Assis and Mark Twain" by Robert Patrick Newcomb (Advisors:  Nelson H. Vieira and Luiz F. Valente)</li>
<li>"The Documentary in My Mind: Story of a  Generation 1945-1976" by Karina Diana Saltman (Advisors: Nelson H.  Vieira and Thomas E. Skidmore)</li>
<li>"Women, Revolution and Socialism: The  Mozambican Experience" by Lissett Costa Ferreira (Advisors: Lina  Fruzzetti and OnÃ©simo T. Almeida)</li>
<li>"Same Shore, Different Faces: Brazilian and  Japanese-Brazilian Perspectives on Japan" by Elizabeth Domingues Matos  (Advisors: Jeffrey Lesser and Nelson Vieira)</li>
<li>"The Decolonizing Cannibal: Three  Contemporary Brazilian Artists" by Adele Edelen Nelson (Advisors: Nelson  Vieira and Leonard Tennenhouse)</li>
<li>"Outside Eden: Authoritarianism and Sexuality in Lygia Fagundes Telles's                          As meninas" by Kea Elisabeth Schwiebert (Advisors: Nelson Vieira and Luiz F. Valente)</li>
<li>"The Language Minority Student and the  Public School: Perspectives from the Portuguese-Speaking Community" by  Monica Teixeira de Sousa (Advisors: Nelson Vieira and Maria Pacheco)</li>
<li>"Liberating and Liberation: Contemporary                          ConscientizaÃ§Ã£oin Brazilian Adult Literacy" by Leigh H. Scott (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente and Maria Pacheco)</li>
<li>"Up Against the Wall: Tensions Between  Citizen Participation and the Brazilian Justice System" by Martin S.  Small (Advisors: Thomas E. Skidmore and Paulo SÃ©rgio Pinheiro)</li>
<li>"Escaping Blackness: The Brazilian  Construction of National Identity and Its Implications for  Afro-Brazilians" by Adjoa F. Jones de Almeida (Advisors: Anani  Dzidzienyo and Thomas E. Skidmore)</li>
<li>"To Punish or Not to Punish: Domestic  Violence and the Criminal Justice System in Brazil" by Karina P. Lago  (Advisors: Nelson H. Vieira and Thomas E. Skidmore)                          <strong>(Awarded the Helen Terry MacLeod Prize for the outstanding thesis on women and gender)</strong></li>
<li>"From Industrialization to Privatization: A  Chronicle of Brazil's Steel Industry" by Benjamin D. Goodman (Advisors:  Liliana Acero and Thomas E. Skidmore)</li>
<li>"Populism and the Legacy of Vargas:  Continuity in Brazilian Politics 1930-1992" by Sandra Forero RincÃ³n  (Advisors: Thomas E. Skidmore and Hector Schamis)</li>
<li>"Aracruz Celulose S.A.: A Brazilian Kraft  Pulp Company Confronts Sustainable Development" by Meredith M. Persily  (Advisors: Thomas E. Skidmore and Thomas Biersteker)</li>
<li>"Cape Verdeans in Pursuit of the American  Dream: Transcending Theories of 'Making It' in America, Moving Towards a  Self-Definition" by Grace E. Mitchell (Advisors: Adeline Becker and  Luiz F. Valente)</li>
<li>"Crisis and Fulfillment: Storytelling in  Essas Malditas Mulheres" by Jacob C. Miller (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente  and Nelson H. Vieira)</li>
<li>"Conflict, Compression and Conciliation: The  Liberal and Conservative Parties of Mid-Nineteenth-Century Brazil" by  Adam D. Culbreath (Advisors: Thomas E. Skidmore and Luiz F. Valente)</li>
<li>"Re-Inventing Afro-Braziliana: A Study of  Race, Racism and Religion through the Brazilian Press" by Deborah L.  Moore (Advisors: Anani Dzidzienyo and Nelson H. Vieira)</li>
<li>"Household Survival Strategies in a  Brazilian Urban Squatter Settlement: An Analysis of Women's Behavior in  SÃ£o GonÃ§alo, Bahia" by Loral Patchen (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente and  Thomas E. Skidmore)</li>
<li>"From Purity of Blood to Racial Democracy:  The Evolution of Brazilian Racial Ideology and Its Political, Social and  Economic Effects" by Paul M. Zimmerman (Advisors: Anani Dzidzienyo and  Anita Novisnky)</li>
<li>"Imagery in the Short Fiction of Clarice Lispector" by Maureen E. Comfort (Advisors: Luiz F. Valente and Nelson H. Vieira)</li>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Fellowships, Prizes, and Funding</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-225" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Various prizes, fellowships, and research funds are available to undergraduate students in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies. <span>Students planning to apply for fellowships should  make their  intention known to the Concentration Advisor as early as  possible to  avoid missing deadlines.<span> <br /></span></span></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<h2><span><a name="scarritt"></a>The John and Clarice Scarritt Fund</span></h2>
<p><span>The Scarritt Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies has been  established by Clarice and John A. Scarritt '73, P'09 to support trips  to Brazil by Brown undergraduates for the purpose of conducting research  for theses and participating in internships. Priority is given to  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators and to non-concentrators  who have demonstrated a commitment to Portuguese and Brazilian Studies  through coursework and participation in departmental activities. </span></p>
<p><span>For  more information, please contact Professors <a href="mailto:Patricia_Sobral@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Patricia Sobral</a> and/or <a href="mailto:Luiz_Valente@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Luiz F. Valente<span></span></a>. You can also <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.portuguese-brazilian-studies/files/uploads/ScarrittFundApplication.pdf" title="Scarritt Fund Application">download the application</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/scarritt-fund-projects" title="Scarritt Fund Projects" rel="nofollow">projects that have been supported by the Scarritt Fund</a>.<br /></span></p>
<h2><a name="karina"></a>Karina P. Lago Prize</h2>
<p>Each year one or two senior concentrators are recommended for a  special  prize at graduation. This award recognizes outstanding academic   achievement in the Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentration. In   1995 the award was renamed in memory of Karina Palmira Lago'95, an   outstanding student and exemplary human being, who passed away on   November 6, 1995. The prize was endowed in December, 1997 by a generous   gift from Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Small '63, P '97.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>Learn more about the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/karina-lago-memorial-fund-portuguese-and-brazilian-studies" title="Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" rel="nofollow">Karina Lago Fund</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/karina-p-lago-prize-recipients" title="Karina P. Lago Prize Recipients" rel="nofollow">previous recipients of the prize.</a></span></p>
<h2>Other Fellowships and Honors</h2>
<p>Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators have also competed favorably for national fellowships and university-wide honors:</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<p>Rotary Fellowship</p>
</td>

</td>
</tr>

</td>

Nelson '99<br />Monica Teixeira de Sousa '98<br />Daniel Perlin '97.5<br />Martin S. Small '97<br />Karina P. Lago '95<br />Adjoa F. Jones de Almeida '95<br />Vicki A. Meyer '94<br />Kristen M. <p>A large number of Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies concentrators have graduated <strong>"magna cum laude."</strong></p>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Fellowships, Prizes, and Funding</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-225" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Various prizes, fellowships, and research funds are available to undergraduate students in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies. <span>Students planning to apply for fellowships should  make their  intention known to the Concentration Advisor as early as  possible to  avoid missing deadlines.<span> <br /></span></span></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<h2><span><a name="scarritt"></a>The John and Clarice Scarritt Fund</span></h2>
<p><span>The Scarritt Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies has been  established by Clarice and John A. Scarritt '73, P'09 to support trips  to Brazil by Brown undergraduates for the purpose of conducting research  for theses and participating in internships. Priority is given to  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators and to non-concentrators  who have demonstrated a commitment to Portuguese and Brazilian Studies  through coursework and participation in departmental activities. </span></p>
<p><span>For  more information, please contact Professors <a href="mailto:Patricia_Sobral@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Patricia Sobral</a> and/or <a href="mailto:Luiz_Valente@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Luiz F. Valente<span></span></a>. You can also <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.portuguese-brazilian-studies/files/uploads/ScarrittFundApplication.pdf" title="Scarritt Fund Application">download the application</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/scarritt-fund-projects" title="Scarritt Fund Projects" rel="nofollow">projects that have been supported by the Scarritt Fund</a>.<br /></span></p>
<h2><a name="karina"></a>Karina P. Lago Prize</h2>
<p>Each year one or two senior concentrators are recommended for a  special  prize at graduation. This award recognizes outstanding academic   achievement in the Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentration. In   1995 the award was renamed in memory of Karina Palmira Lago'95, an   outstanding student and exemplary human being, who passed away on   November 6, 1995. The prize was endowed in December, 1997 by a generous   gift from Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Small '63, P '97.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><span>Learn more about the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates/karina-lago-memorial-fund-portuguese-and-brazilian-studies" title="Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" rel="nofollow">Karina Lago Fund</a> or view <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/karina-p-lago-prize-recipients" title="Karina P. Lago Prize Recipients" rel="nofollow">previous recipients of the prize.</a></span></p>
<h2>Other Fellowships and Honors</h2>
<p>Portuguese and Brazilian Studies concentrators have also competed favorably for national fellowships and university-wide honors:</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>

</td>

Nelson '99<br />Monica Teixeira de Sousa '98<br />Daniel Perlin '97.5<br />Martin S. Small '97<br />Karina P. Lago '95<br />Adjoa F. Jones de Almeida '95<br />Vicki A. Meyer '94<br />Kristen M. <p>A large number of Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies concentrators have graduated <strong>"magna cum laude."</strong></p>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-227" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>The Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</strong> was  endowed by a generous gift from Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Small '63, P  '97, and has been augmented by contributions from alumni, parents,  faculty and friends of the department. The fund supports the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates#karina" title="Resources for Undergraduates" rel="nofollow">Karina P.  Lago Prize</a>, awarded annually to an outstanding concentrator in  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies, as well as other departmental  activities, such as guest lectures, artistic performances, and  colloquia. Contributions to the Karina Lago Memorial Fund in Portuguese  and Brazilian Studies should be sent to Professor Nelson H. Vieira,  Chair, Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies, Box O, Brown  University, RI 02912.</p>
<h2>Karina Palmira Lago '95</h2>
<p>Karina P. Lago was born in Uruguay, and educated in her native  country and in the United States. She was graduated from Brown magna cum  laude and with honors in Portuguese and Brazilian Studies in 1995. At  graduation she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and was awarded the  Portuguese and Brazilian Studies Honors Prize and the Emery Fellowship  for Graduate Studies. Her honors thesis, entitled "To Punish or Not to  Punish: Domestic Violence and the Criminal Justice in Brazil," received  the Helen Terry Mac Leod Prize as the outstanding thesis focusing on  women and gender.</p>
<p>Karina participated in the Brown-in-Brazil Program at the  Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro in the fall of 1993, and returned  to Brazil in the summer of 1994 to work as an intern in the Political  and Economic Office of the United States Consulate General in Rio de  Janeiro. Karina was admired by her teachers for her intelligence,  creativity and uncompromising honesty, and was highly respected by her  peers in the Portuguese and Brazilian Studies Program as well as in the  Brown University Hispanic Community, for whom she was a role model. At  the time of her untimely death on November 6, 1995, Karina was a  graduate student at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in Medford,  Massachusetts.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
  </div>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>

  <div id="content">

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Scarritt Fund Projects</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-228" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The following projects have been supported by the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/resources-undergraduates#scarritt" title="Resources for Undergraduates" rel="nofollow">Scarritt Fund</a>:</p>
<h6>JESSICA VOSBURG '07.5</h6>
<p>An investigation of Rio de Janeiro's NGOs that teach dance,  film, theater, digital production, and other arts to young people from  Rio's poorest and most violent neighborhoods with the goal of assessing  how dynamic artist expression , often viewed as an apolitical luxury of  the First World, may play a central role in development. This research  resulted into an honors thesis in Development Studies presented in  December'07.</p>
<h6>SAMUEL NOVACICH '08</h6>
<p>An examination of public opinion and popular responses to the  violence that currently plagues the city of Rio de Janeiro through a  series of interviews with academics, NGO leaders and the Commission on  Human Rights of the Order of Brazilian Lawyers (OAB). This research  became part of an honors thesis in Latin American Studies presented in  May'08.</p>
<h6>HANNAH OLSEN '10</h6>
<p>Internship with the "Cinema Nosso" NGO in Rio de Janeiro, which  uses film to connect poor urban youth to training in media skills and  access to the arts job market.</p>
<h6>CHANEY HARRISON '11 AND FINN YARBROUGH '09</h6>
<p>Through collaboration with the Brazilian NGO Cinema Nosso, Hope  High School and Brown University, Harrison and Yarbrough will develop a  series of workshops to provide basic technical skills in audio-visual  work to at-risk youth in Rio de Janeiro while exploring storytelling  through film as a method for engaging and empowering them to pursue  their own social and educational development. The ultimate goal is to  produce a documentary based on Cinema Nosso's impact on their lives.</p>
<h6>TAYLOR BARNES '09</h6>
<p>Travelled to Rio de Janeiro in January 2009 in order to try her  hand  as a freelance journalist. The result was an approximately  thousand-word business article published in the Miami Herald on January  26, 2009.</p>
<h6>DIEGO GILSANZ '11</h6>
<p>Travelled to Rio de Janeiro to spend the summer of 2009 interning  at the Instituto de Estudos do Trabalho     and Sociedade (Institute for the Study of Labor and Society), a  multi-disciplinary non-profit organization known for its research on  poverty and social inequality. IETS serves as a connection between  academic research, public policy, the private sector and  non-governmental organizations.</p>
<h6>IMANI CARLA TISDALE '12</h6>
<p>Participated in an internship at Adami Advogados  Associados, in  Rio de Janeiro, an internationally acclaimed law firm committed  to  human rights, civil rights, racial equality, workers' rights and the   environment.</p>
<h6>JOSHUA ROWE '12</h6>
<p>Participated in a research internship  with  Conectas Direitos Humanos, in SÃ£o Paulo. Conectas sponsors visits  to Brazil by  human rights activists from Angola, Mozambique, Guinea  Bissau and Cape Verde.  Joshua worked directly with the Conectas  exchange program, while also pursuing research  of his own design,  presented as a culmination of his internship project.</p>
<h6>FRANCISCO OLIVEIRA '13</h6>
<p>Participated in an engineering  internships with  Metalfran, a company in Volta Reddonda, Brazil, which  specializes in making  structures from metal, aluminum, steel and glass  for such companies and  Peugeot, Volkswagen and regional Brazilian  hotels. Francisco worked directly  with the CEO, helping plan, budget  and organize projects, while also assisting  with the manufacturing of  products. He aso observed other fields of engineering  at a local  technical school.</p>
<h6>SOHUM  CHATTERJEE '14 AND SIME LUKETA '14</h6>
<p>Travelled to Salvador and Rio  de Janeiro with the  African-American Baptist Church of Brown University as  neutral  observers to Brazilian culture and society. They observed how ethnic  diversity within the community, and differences in religion  and culture  have resulted in differential development of the community. Interacted  with communities of different faiths (Baptist, Candomble, Umbanda,  Catholic, etc.) and investigated contemporary racial  definition  conditions within religious  institutions. Their work included visiting  religious institutions such  as RosÃ¡rio dos Pretos, Igreja de Batista de  GarÃ§a de Esperanca, Igreja Universal do  Reino de Deus, Igreja Batista  de ItapoÃ£, Igreja de Batista de Ipanema and cultural events such as the  Lavagem do  Bonfim.</p>
<h6>REXY JOSH DORADO '14</h6>
<p>Spent  three months in Rio de Janeiro interning with Catalytic  Communities, a  nonprofit that works to train, assist, and advocate for  community leaders and  entrepreneurs within the city's favelas, and  reported his observations on  the RioOnWatch website.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h6><strong>LANNA MARIE LEITE '14</strong></h6>
<p>Traveled to Brazil in order to conduct research for her honors thesis, which focuses on the personal narrative of Maria Auxiliadora Lara Barcelos (known as Dora), a guerilla fighter and activist during the military regime (1964-1985), as a way to understand the complexities of the resistance against the regime. The investigation centers on two questions: What does Maria Auxiliadoraâs story say about the guerilla resistance in the 1960s-1980s? What are the implications of Brazilâs Truth Commission for the role and memory of the guerilla movement?</p>
<h6>NICHOLAS HIRSCHFELD â14.5</h6>
<p>Internship at a media production company called Giros, under the supervision of Brown alumnus Adam Stepan'89. His main project there, done in conjunction with the Columbia University Global Center in Rio de Janeiro, was to develop the online (and video) components to a hybrid educational program that would allow professors from Columbia's School for International and Public Administration (SIPA) to train Brazilian public servants. In addition, I contributed to a market study of the Brazilian public sector that demonstrated the need for such a program in Brazil.</p>
<h6>DEVON M. REYNOLDS â14</h6>
<p>Spent the summer of 2013 in. the city of Altamira, ParÃ¡ where she conducted sociological research on the relationship between the construction of the Belo Monte dam and the Altamira fishing community as part of a group led by Professor Leah Van Wey.</p>
<h6>MATEUS BAPTISTA â14</h6>
<p>As part of his honors thesis research, Mateus spent the summer of 2013 in Brazil interviewing people involved with the Instituto Liberal. The institute began in the late 1970s by Brazilian businessman named Donald Stewart. He was interested in the ways that the institute assisted in dissemination neoliberal policies throughout Brazil. He also established contact with professors at the University of SÃ£o Paulo for further discussions on the intersection of neoliberal economic policies and US foreign policy.</p>
<h6>ANTONIA PICCONE â14.5</h6>
<p>Traveled to Brazil during the 2014 winter break to conduct research for her honors thesis, in which she analyzes the historical role that the circus played in the formation and evolution of Brazilâs cultural identity. As a circus performer herself, she had always been fascinated with anything and everything circus-related. At age sixteen, she embarked on a trip to South America where she spent two months training at a circus school in Chile. There she reflected for the first time on the larger cultural significance of the circus in South America.</p>
<h6>MARGA KEMPNER â15</h6>
<p>Spent three weeks in Rio de Janeiro three weeks in the summer of 2014, working closely with the Arruda family to conduct interviews, collect footage, and digitize photographs in order to document their lives during the 1964-1985 military regime. Their story was one of loss and exile, but also of tireless resistance and political activism. One of the family members, Marcos, was arrested and tortured in 1970 by the regime after having joined the clandestine resistance movement, AÃ§Ã£o Popular. In 1971, he was able to escape to the U.S., where he continued his work to fight political oppression (he now lives in Rio). His younger siblings, MÃ´nica, Martinha, and Miguel, also became committed to the struggle for democratization, and from them she learned about the role of women in the resistance, the emergence of the arts as an important place to criticize the regime, the effects of political repression, and the legacy of the dictatorship in terms of current economic inequality in Brazil. The memoir that Marcos Arruda and his mother wrote, titled <em>A Motherâs Cry</em>, is the only account of torture written by Brazilians that has been published in English. For this reason, it is especially important to make sure their story lives on. She completed post-production editing by December 2014.</p>
<h6>MIRIAM HINTHORN â16</h6>
<p>Traveled to Brazil to conduct research for her thesis on accountability and transparency in Brazilian governance. She met with public civil servants, academic researchers, and civil society actors. She connected especially well with two researchers with whom she worked on an article about the Law of Access to Information.</p>
<h6>CAMILA MCHUGH â15</h6>
<p>Traveled to SÃ£o Paulo during the winter 2015 break to conduct research for her honors thesis in Comparative Literature, part of which focuses on Michel Laubâs recent novel, <em>DiÃ¡rio da Queda</em>. The novel grapples with questions of memory in contemporary Brazil, also investigating the way in which the Holocaust and Alzheimerâs disease complicate the stakes of memory. She met with Mr. Laub and connected with professors in Comparative and Contemporary Literature, Memory Studies and Jewish studies.</p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Study Abroad</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-201" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Study either in Brazil or in Portugal (usually in the junior year or  during the summer) is strongly encouraged as an important part of the  concentration. Up to four credits from participation in foreign-study  programs can be applied towards the concentration in Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies.</p>
<h2>Brown Programs</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/study-abroad/brown-brazil-program" title="The Brown-in-Brazil Program" rel="nofollow">The Brown-in-Brazil Program</a></li>
<li><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/academic-year-portugal" title="Academic Year in Portugal" rel="nofollow">Academic Year in Portugal</a></li>
<li><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/study-abroad/summer-study-brazil" title="Summer Study in Brazil" rel="nofollow">Summer Study in Brazil</a></li>
<li><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/study-abroad/summer-study-portugal" title="Summer Study in Portugal" rel="nofollow">Summer Study in Portugal</a></li>
</ul>
<p>For further information about Study Abroad, including non-Brown programs, <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/college/special-programs/international-study/" title="OIP">consult Brown's Office of International Programs (OIP).</a></p>
<h2>Preparation</h2>
<p>Students should begin to prepare early for  participation in such programs. For example, keep in mind that students intending to participate in the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/study-abroad/brown-brazil-program" title="The Brown-in-Brazil Program" rel="nofollow">Brown-in-Brazil Program</a> who begin the study of Portuguese as sophomores should start with Intensive Portuguese (POBS 0110) so that they can complete POBS 0400 (a prerequisite for participation in the program) in the spring semester. Other programs may have different requirements.</p>
<fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-links"><legend>Related Links</legend><div class="field field-type-link field-field-related-links">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">
                    <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/college/special-programs/international-study/">Office of International Programs</a>        </div>
              <div class="field-item even">
                    <a href="http://brown.edu/Administration/Registrar/">Office of the Registrar</a>        </div>
        </div>
</div>
</fieldset>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">

</article>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">The Brown-in-Brazil Program</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-219" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>(PUC-Rio de Janeiro)</strong><strong><br />Professor Luiz F. Valente, Director&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p>One of the original <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/college/special-programs/international-study/programs/brown-0/brown-brazil" title=" Brown-in-Brazil">Brown-sponsored foreign study programs</a>, the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> was established in 1984 and was located at the Federal University of Bahia until 1990.   In the fall of 1991, it moved to the <a href="http://www.puc-rio.br/" rel="nofollow">Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro (PUC-RIO)</a>,  the oldest private institution of higher learning in Brazil  and one of  the top five Brazilian universities. Although adjustments are   constantly being made in response to changing student needs, the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> has retained its  unique features:</p>
<ul>
<li>Five and a half months of  instruction, as opposed to most  other study-abroad programs in Brazil,  which generally offer only four months</li>
<li>High academic standards</li>
<li>Outstanding support services, including close  supervision by a  local faculty coordinator as well as the comprehensive  facilities of  <a href="http://www.puc-rio.br/ccci/" rel="nofollow">PUC-Rio's Office of International Programs (CCCI)</a><span></span></li>
</ul>
<h2>Who can participate?</h2>
<p>The program is designed  for students who have the equivalent of at  least three semesters of language  instruction, preferably POBS 0110 and POBS 0400, plus at least one  related course on Brazil in  another discipline, such as Literature, History,  Political Science,  Sociology, Development Studies, Africana Studies, etc.</p>
<p>Although the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> was originally   designed for Brown undergraduates, it is open to students from other   universities. In the past the program has welcomed students from the  following  universities: Colorado, Columbia, Connecticut College,  Cornell, Duke, Harvard, Johns  Hopkins, Middlebury, Mount Holyoke, Notre Dame,  Pennsylvania, Princeton, Smith,  Tulane, Vanderbilt, Vassar, Virginia,  Washington, Wesleyan, and Yale.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h2><span>Program Structure</span></h2>
<p><span>Students participating in  the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> have the   option of spending the <strong>fall semester (August 1-December 15)</strong> or the  <strong>full  academic year (July 1-June 30)</strong> at PUC-Rio.</span></p>
<h4>Orientation</h4>
<p><span>The fall semester is  preceded by a <strong>mandatory</strong> five-week, intensive orientation session (July 1-Aug 7), which is included in the  semester tuition <em>at no additional cost</em>.  The orientation session includes  two modules: </span></p>
<ol>
<li><span>Four weeks of  intensive instruction in Portuguese language and  Brazilian culture,  with three hours of scheduled classes every day, additional  lectures by  various noted specialists twice a week, and field trips to historical   towns like Paraty and PetrÃ³polis, as well as within the city of Rio.<br /></span></li>
<li><span>A  week-long seminar on Afro-Brazilian culture, held in Salvador,  Bahia between  the conclusion of the intensive course and the beginning  of the academic  semester, with airfare, hotel, lectures, field trips,  and most meals covered by  the program.<span> <br /></span></span></li>
</ol>
<h4>Academic Program</h4>
<p><span>During  the academic semester(s) <strong>Brown-in-Brazil</strong> students  enroll in a maximum of four courses, to be chosen from the offerings  of  any unit of the university, provided that the appropriate prerequisites  can  be met. One of the courses may be replaced by an independent  study. For Brown  students these independent studies generally take the  shape of a <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/college/special-programs/international-study/programs/global-independent-study-glisp">"Global  Independent Study Project" or GLISP</a>.  Upon completion of the academic program, students are issued an  official  transcript documenting their work at PUC. Normally students  are able to  transfer up to the equivalent of four Brown courses per  semester for  participation in the program.</span></p>
<h4>Special Events</h4>
<p>Additional trips as well  as other program-specific events take  place at various points in the academic  semester. Among them is a  dinner in early August with representatives from  various organizations  for the purpose of assisting participants in possibly  securing unpaid  internships or opportunities for volunteer work.</p>
<h4>Housing</h4>
<p>Participants are housed  with local families. Although it is  preferred that they will stay with their  host families for the duration  of the program, students are allowed to make  alternative housing  arrangements, such as apartments, after the first two  months. All  housing changes must be approved by the local coordinator and  students  must give their host families proper notice. Students from other   universities who are participating in the program may need to secure  permission  from their home institutions to move into apartments.</p>
<h4>Supervision</h4>
<p>The program is supervised  by the Brown campus Director,  Professor Luiz F. Valente, and by the local Coordinator  at PUC-Rio,  Professor Karl Erik SchÃ¸llhammer.</p>
<p>The <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> was created by the  <a href="http://brown.edu/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/home">Department of Portuguese  and Brazilian Studies</a>, which continues to have  close involvement with its  operation. The <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> is the only program in Brazil supported by the Department of Portuguese and  Brazilian Studies.</p>
<h4>To Apply</h4>
<p>The  deadline for applications to the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong> is March 1.</p>
<p><span>For more information about the <strong>Brown-in-Brazil Program</strong>, please contact <a href="mailto:Luiz_Valente@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Professor Valente</a> or visit the <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/college/special-programs/international-study/">Office for International Programs</a>.<span>&nbsp;</span><span><br /></span></span></p>

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Summer Study in Brazil</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-221" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Brown currently does not sponsor a summer program in Brazil. Students  interested in spending a summer studying in Brazil should consider  <a href="http://www.puc-rio.br/ensinopesq/ccci/portuguese.html" rel="nofollow">PUC-Rio's "Pre-Term Portuguese-as-a-Second-Language Course,"</a> which is run separately from the <a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/undergraduate/study-abroad/brown-brazil-program" title="The Brown-in-Brazil Program" rel="nofollow">Brown-in-Brazil Program</a>.  Alternatively, they may consider summer programs sponsored by other  universities, such as the <a href="http://spanishandportuguese.ufl.edu/study-abroad-programs/uf-in-rio-de-janeiro/" rel="nofollow">University of Florida</a>.</p>
<p>For more information about summer programs in Brazil, please contact Professor <a href="mailto:Luiz_Valente@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Luiz F. Valente</a>.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>

        <div class="item-list">

<div class="banner-text">
				<h1><a href="/academics/portuguese-brazilian-studies/" title="Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies" accesskey="2"><span class="site-title">Department of Portuguese and Brazilian Studies</span></a></h1><div id="site-slogan" class="slogan banner-subtext"></div>			</div></section>
		    
  <!-- Layout -->
  <div id="content">

                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Summer Study in Portugal</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-222" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Students interested in spending a summer in Portugal normally attend  the Summer Program at the <a href="http://www.ulisboa.pt/" rel="nofollow">University of Lisbon</a>. Students who complete  this program may be granted one unassigned credit in Portuguese. Small  grants from the <a href="https://www.instituto-camoes.pt/" rel="nofollow">Instituto CamÃµes</a> are generally available for  participation in this program.</p>
<p>For more information about summer programs in Portugal, please contact Professors <a href="mailto:Onesimo_Almeida@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">OnÃ©simo T. Almeida</a> or <a href="mailto:Leonor_Goncalves_Simas-Almeida@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Leonor Simas-Almeida</a>.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
  </div>

	
  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">


	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
